Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Mapping a Pathway to College Using Predictive Analytic Modeling and Decision Support
Award.AbstractNarration:
The SBIR Phase I project supports six months of R/R & D to develop a goal-setting and planning software tool for students from 5th to 12th grade and their families, not unlike current tools for financial planning or trip planning. Students and families will benefit from the power of prediction-based goal setting as well as an early warning system that indicates when students are off track of their education goal, and evidence-based program suggestions to get students back on track of their goal. Navigating the education system in the U.S. is complex, even more so for first-generation college seekers and new immigrant students and families. Between 9th grade and the first year of college, 50% of America's students fall off the path toward higher education even as research shows that students cannot make a living wage without a post-secondary diploma. Today, nearly every U.S. school offers an electronic grade book and a parent portal that shares student performance data with students and their families. This SBIR-sponsored tool would integrate seamlessly with these existing portals to offer added-value features to a system that has not changed in over 15 years. With notoriously poor counselor-to-students ratio of 471:1, and with the uneven distribution of access to supports (such as private counseling services for those who can afford it), technology such as this may very well serve as a leveling instrument in U.S. schools. SBIR support provides the opportunity for technology transfer of what we know about financial planning and business practices to inform education planning and goal-setting based purely on data analytics and best practices.

This SBIR-sponsored innovation harnesses the advances of business intelligence and decision support intelligence and applies it to education. This is a new-to-the-market tool with graphic displays of data, progress mapping, predictive analytics, research-based and customized interventions associated with improved student outcomes, all within parent portal systems that are widely used across the U.S. This web and mobile-enabled tool monitors performance and progress, not unlike what the mobile wrist band devices that offer health enthusiasts today. After initial 6 months of funding, the project will have determined proper alignment of data sets for analytic purposes, will have developed predictive analytic models using de-identified student data, will have developed a data visualization dashboard that showcases the power of this forward-looking tool on school web-based platforms, and will have conducted feedback sessions with customers on their interest level, ease of use, and accuracy of predictive outcomes. The methods used will include multiple regression, logistic regression and descriptive analysis. Prediction accuracy will be evaluated by logistic regression and ROC curve analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There isn’t a day that goes by without public discussion or the press pointing out some issue, concern or flaw about the American education system. In truth, the issues are complex and the variables are numerous. All the while, taxpayers want actionable, evidence-based results for the dollars they pour into education. UR TURN, in response, aims to be a problem-solving and decision-making tool that is in the hands of those users closest to the educational experience: the student and, at best, their family.

Reams of data points are available to help us quantify the problems and identify pain points in education. But what is often missing for students and their families is a context in which to place these data points. UR TURN not only provides the context, it also takes individual data (collected by the school, the school district, the state and the federal government along with private testing companies), gives data meaning and provides a data dashboard that illustrates key turning points and benchmarks. The dashboard goes farther by forecasting where a student’s pathway is likely to take them. If the pathway deviates from a goal that a student has set, UR TURN provides research-based interventions that are known to improve outcomes, thus moving a student closer to their goal.

Data analysis. Goal-setting. Decision-making. The thinking behind UR TURN is not unlike tools used by financial planners in helping individuals reach their financial goals. And what research shows about financial planning and financial literacy is that future-oriented planning and assessment tools are associated with an array of positive financial outcomes (Lynch, Netemeyer, Spiller & Zammit, 2010).

The engine behind UR TURN is also not unlike business intelligence software which is used to analyze a private company’s raw data. Companies use business intelligence (BI) to improve decision-making and to identify new opportunities. BI tools are used everywhere from restaurant chains to baseball teams, and have democratized the way in which the software allows users to analyze data themselves, rather than depending on an IT department to run complex reports. This democratization of information and analytics has moved business decision-making away from gut feelings and anecdotes and toward an improved bottom line (Thierauf, 2001; Negash & Gray, 2008).

The same democratization of data use and technology transfer needs to be done for students. With notoriously poor counselor-to-students ratio of 471:1 in the U.S., and with the uneven distribution of access to supports (ranging from high-priced tutors to private counseling services for those who can afford it), technology may very well serve as the moderating instrument that level-izes the playing field. What these NSF grant dollars return to the taxpayers is the transfer of what we know about financial planning and business practices to education planning, goal- setting and decision-making that is based on research and data analytics. UR TURN harnesses the volume of data points that our multiple government- supported systems have collected and it applies planning and business intelligence to one of our most important forms of capital: human capital. 

 


Last Modified: 06/15/2016
Modified by: Angela M Eilers
